results.title: Landscape as Character
results.brief_description: The Australian landscape is never just a setting. It’s meditative, motivational and menacing; a character that empowers, intimidates and inspires. This artwork examines how representations of Australian landscapes have evolved from being dominated by the Outback to the suburbs and cities.

constellations_primary.name: Landscape as Character
constellations_primary.description: The landscape is often a character in Australian films. Usually, it's a villain that represents our problematic national character and is increasingly used to challenge our troubled history and explore our evolving identities.

results.description:
Australia’s First Peoples are connected to Country through thousands of generations of kinship ties. We derive our identity, culture, law and knowledge from Country – something we express and uphold through moving image storytelling. Through the screen, we’re able to tell our story of survival against the violence of colonisation, ensuring our connection and re-connection to Country endures from the past to today.

The Australian landscape is never just a setting. It’s meditative, motivational and menacing; a character that empowers, intimidates and inspires. For years, the Outback has dominated Australian screen stories, but representations have sprawled into the suburbs and cities, creating compelling and complex characters on our screens.
description_for_label:
Australia’s First Peoples are connected to Country through thousands of generations of kinship ties. We derive our identity, culture, law and knowledge from Country – something we express and uphold through moving image storytelling. Through the screen, we’re able to tell our story of survival against the violence of colonisation, ensuring our connection and re-connection to Country endures from the past to today.

The Australian landscape is never just a setting. It’s meditative, motivational and menacing; a character that empowers, intimidates and inspires. For years, the Outback has dominated Australian screen stories, but representations have sprawled into the suburbs and cities, creating compelling and complex characters on our screens.

results.title: Landscape after battle
results.creator_credit: Polish Corporation for Film Production and Andrzej Wajda
results.brief_description: World War 2 has ended, but former prisoners of the Nazis are left with emotional scars. Life outside the camp is now unknown and unimaginable. A small group of survivors wait for their futures to be decided in an old army barracks. Two members of the group begin an affair, until the woman is accidentally killed by an American guard. Based on the stories of Tadeusz Borowski, an Auschwitz survivor. An examination of life after witnessing and living through the holocaust. Nominated for the Palme d’Or award at the Cannes Film Festival in 1970. In Polish with English subtitles.

results.title: Landscape & cityscape
results.creator_credit: Sandra Ostertag, Holt, Rinehart and Winston, CBS, KOCE-TV (Television station : Huntington Beach, Calif.) and Coast Community Colleges
results.brief_description:
Episode number 15 of Series “The Photographic vision”.
Traces the impact of the romantic movement in art on the landscape theme. Features Ansel Adams and shows several of his works. Several guest photographers also describe their approaches to their work and the results they achieve.

results.title: Landscape
results.creator_credit: Peter Riding and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Exploring Photography”.
Deals with a wide variety of approaches to landscape photography, including the adventurous work of Ernst Haas and the more symbolic black and white of John Blakemore. Presented by Bryn Campbell.

results.title: Landscape
results.creator_credit: ZKM Institut fur Bildmedien, Karlsruhe, Anna Szepesi and Tamas Waliczky
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and audio
results.brief_description: In a small German village, time stops in the middle of a storm. Raindrops glitter frozen in the air, and the only living thing is the roving eye of the camera which moves through this frozen moment of time. Using complex digital animation techniques, Tamas Waliczky invites the viewer to reimagine how time and space are perceived and proposes a new virtual experience of the body’s movement through space.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ZKM Institut fur Bildmedien, Karlsruhe, Anna Szepesi and Tamas Waliczky

results.title: Lands apart
results.brief_description: In this story Cathy tells the story of her parents who migrated to Australia and thanks them ” for your strength and the sacrifices you made to give us a better life” Created as part of the Racconti: La Voce del Popolo Digital Storytelling in association with The Italian Federation of Migrant Workers and their Families (FILEF).

results.title: Landline: Stripping the Myth
results.brief_description:
‘Landline’ is the ABC’s national rural issues program.

This episode investigates the conventionally accepted history of the invention and development of the combine harvester. The widely held belief that a young Victorian, Hugo Victor McKay, was the inventor of the world’s first such machine is exposed as a myth.

First broadcast on 13th March, 2005.

results.title: Landholder Group Participation: a Model for Action
results.creator_credit: Peter Mountjoy and Warrenbayne Boho Land Protection Group
results.brief_description: Shows the process of landholders realising that the problems of salinity and erosion need to be tackled in groups rather than as individuals. Illustrates the establishment of the Warrenbayne Boho Land Protection Group. Shows the group working with Agriculture Extension Officers and Soil Conservation personnel, owning their involvement and taking responsibility for their actions. Useful as a model for people planning to establish community action groups.
